docs.lead_paragraph: About to be pushed by Republican leaders into an uncomfortable vote against capping medical malpractice awards, Senate Democrats joined today with a freshman Republican, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, to strike back with a malpractice bill of their own. ''I am going to fight this bill,'' Mr. Graham said of the Republican legislation, ''because the consequences to everyday Americans would be devastating.''
docs.abstract: Senate Democrats are about to be pushed by Republican leaders into uncomfortable vote against capping medical malpractice awards, but they are striking back with malpractice bill of their own, joined with freshman Republican Lindsey Graham; Republican measure would cap jury awards for pain and suffering at $250,000 in malpractice cases; Graham's measure, co-sponsored by Sen Richard J Durbin, would instead offer tax relief to doctors to help offset their soaring malpractice premiums, create commission to study problem and strip insurance industry of its exemption from federal antitrust laws; emergence of Graham as player in malpractice debate is allowing Democrats to lay claim to measure of bipartisan backing (M)
docs.snippet: About to be pushed by Republican leaders into an uncomfortable vote against capping medical malpractice awards, Senate Democrats joined today with a freshman Republican, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, to strike back with a malpractice bill of...

docs.lead_paragraph: During Schering-Plough's salad days, a bottle of Claritin, the huge-selling allergy pill, fetched as much as $100. But prices are plunging -- soon to as little as $3 for a month's supply -- and the company is reeling. Yesterday, Schering-Plough reported that profits for the second quarter amounted to just 12 cents a share -- down 72 percent from a year ago and a third less than analysts were expecting. Profits in the first quarter were down 71 percent.

headline.main: Schering-Plough Is Hurt by Plummeting Pill Costs

docs.abstract: Schering-Plough Corp reports that profits for second quarter amounted to just 12 cents per share--down 72 percent from year ago and less than analysts were expecting; profits in first quarter were down 71 percent; company says earnings for rest of year will probably be even lower, in part because of growing competition for allergy drug Claritin; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having already delivered President Bush an important vote in favor of a Medicare prescription drug benefit, the Senate today took up another item high on Mr. Bush's domestic agenda: a bill that would impose strict caps on jury awards in medical malpractice cases. At the same time, lawmakers in both chambers scurried to squeeze in work on a series of spending bills before the monthlong August recess.

headline.main: G.O.P. Still Pushes Doomed Malpractice Bill

docs.abstract: Senate takes up bill that would impose strict caps on jury awards in medical malpractice cases, item high on Pres Bush's domestic agenda; Republicans concede that bill, which would cap jury awards for pain and suffering at $250,000, is headed for defeat; measure has no Democratic support in Senate; lawmakers must start work on task of reconciling differences in House and Senate version of prescription drug legislation and measure to extend increase in child tax credit to millions of working families; talks might last into fall; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Having already delivered President Bush an important vote in favor of a Medicare prescription drug benefit, the Senate today took up another item high on Mr. Bush's domestic agenda: a bill that would impose strict caps on jury awards in medical...

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: The House is expected this week to pass legislation ensuring that federal employees, including members of Congress, will have prescription drug benefits better than those available through Medicare when they retire. The bill is being considered as House and Senate leaders begin trying to reconcile different versions of a measure to help Medicare beneficiaries pay for prescription drugs.

headline.main: Plans Improve Federal Workers' Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: House is expected to pass legislation ensuring that federal employees, including members of Congress, will have prescription drug benefits better than those available through Medicare when they retire; at same time, House and Senate leaders are tring to reconcile different versions of measure to help Medicare beneficiaries pay for prescription drugs; new House bill says drug benefits for civilian federal retirees, who already have drug coverage, cannot be reduced to level proposed for Medicare; identical bill has been introduced in Senate; House Republican leaders say they do not consider bill controversial; chart (M)
docs.snippet: The House is expected this week to pass legislation ensuring that federal employees, including members of Congress, will have prescription drug benefits better than those available through Medicare when they retire.    The bill is being considered as...

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost a third of doctors surveyed said they had not told patients about useful treatments because they believed the patients' insurance would not cover them, a study reports today. The practice raises serious ethical issues and appears to be becoming more prevalent, researchers say in the journal Health Affairs.
docs.abstract: Dr Matthew K Wynia, infectious disease specialist and Institute for Ethics director at American Medical Assn, led survey published in journal Health Affairs that shows almost one-third of all doctors admit that they did not tell their patients about potentially beneficial treatments because they felt insurance would not cover them; pitfalls when doctors do not even allow patients their right to appeal denied coverage or choose to pay for treatment independent of coverage discussed (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Protecting America's Health,'' by Philip J. Hilts. Alfred A. Knopf, $26.95. ''A Managed Care Memoir,'' by Dr. Richard L. Reece. Infinity, $19.95.
docs.abstract: Books on Health column explores two books on health care that center on balance between corporate needs and consumer safety; book Protecting America's Health explains and evaluates Food and Drug Administration's more than one century of national care; book's author Philip J Hilts strongly supports public interest over private profits; Dr Richard L Reece book Managed Care Memoir provides guide through HMO's 20-year history and its impact on patient and doctor; photos (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea sounds great in principle. Instead of confining elderly Medicaid patients in nursing homes when they become infirm, why not give them a broad array of options, everything from home care to adult day care centers and assisted living? That would please many of the elderly, who prefer to stay at home near friends and family as long as possible. It would also please state and federal Medicaid administrators, whose budgets are swamped with the high cost of nursing home care for elderly patients. No wonder the Bush administration has encouraged states to experiment with home- or community-based care under so-called Medicaid waivers, and no wonder many governors have responded enthusiastically. The trouble is, in many cases no one seems to be monitoring the quality of the care provided, or even whether it is provided at all. A new report from the General Accounting Office -- described by Robert Pear yesterday in The Times -- lays bare the nature of the problem. While the administration has been boasting about the record number of waivers it has granted, it has not adequately monitored the programs or ensured that the states do so. In many cases, the state waiver programs failed to provide necessary services or adequate nutrition and did not properly assess the needs of patients. How many people have been harmed, if any, is not known because state and federal records are so spotty.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Congress must make sure that home care and independent living as alternative to nursing home really work for elderly Medicaid patients, not just for budgeteers; cites new report from General Accounting Office showing lack of regulation and failure of many states to provide ncesessary services or adequate nutrition
